text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with how not to roast artichokes
that's right I thought I'd come up with
this brilliant idea for stuffing and
roasting artichokes without boiling them
first and it was kind of a joke but
still I think there could be some
valuable lessons here and many of you
seem to like when I screw up so anyway
let me show you what I was trying to do
and then show you what happened so I
started with four beautiful artichokes
except one was not like the other
so you see three of those how the leaves
are very tight you see that one that's
older see how the leaves are spreading
out so you want to get them all is
closed and as tight as you can then I
started prepping them as I always do I
cut off about the first inch and a half
off the top I also cut off the stem so
they'd sit flat in the casserole dish I
rubbed him with lemons so they wouldn't
discolor which is hilarious
since he's basically were dark-brown by
the time I finished and after I'd cut
them and rub them with lemon I took my
hands and I pulled apart those leaves
because what we're gonna do here is
stuff these with a flavorful breadcrumb
stuffing so you want to have space
between the leaves for that stuffing to
nestle down into so those are ready I
went over to a bowl when I dumped in
some bread crumbs some Parmesan cheese
pinch of oregano some black pepper some
cayenne pepper some salt a little bit of
crushed garlic and enough olive oil to
moisten so I'm going to mix that up with
a fork so what my plan was instead of
boiling these first and then roasting
them which is the traditional way to do
stuffed artichokes I was going to stuff
them like this and then roast them raw
and not lose any of that flavor into the
blanching liquid that you may and the
traditional method so basically I'm just
smooshing those flavorful breadcrumbs in
between as many leaves as possible and
when those were all stuffed I put them
in a casserole dish that I'd lined with
some parchment paper and because these
were not blanched first I figured you
know what you better put a little water
at the bottom of the pan to add a little
humidity to the oven so I popped those
in a 375 degree oven and I figured an
hour later they would be just about
right so I pulled him out I started
testing them with a fork and now I'm not
going into a dream sequence
that's just steamed and I want to test
it and I was like man that is still
super hard
so I said to myself you know what when
in doubt drizzle them with lemon juice
in olive oil which I did I also gave
another shot of parmesan and I figured
just thrown back in for another few
minutes and they'll be fine
so that's what I did toss them back in
gave another 20 minutes pulled him out
they look pretty good I was so excited
to eat until I felt it with the fork and
guess what still very hard even though I
could kind of pull out a leaf it still
was just not tender at all and I was
getting you know slightly disappointed
and filled with rage so I decided
extreme measures were in order so I put
in another little splash of water I went
ahead and covered it with foil because
clearly at this point my roasting them
uncovered without blanching the first
idea was a failure so I wrapped him up
nice and tight put it back in the oven I
figured I'll give him a half-hour more
for sure they will be done took him out
half-hour later
felt him with a fork and yes finally
they still were not done I tried one not
bad but still not really tender I
decided to uncover them throw some more
cheese on and put him back in until they
really really really were done I tested
them with a fork every ten minutes or so
until finally almost two and a half
hours later they were done and they
looked horrific well actually maybe
that's not horrific maybe that is
actually really cool-looking depends on
your point of view but at least they
were tender at least the inside was soft
I served it with a little lemon and by
this time I was so hungry remember I
thought I was going to eat these like an
hour and a half ago now as far as the
final flavor the final taste incredible
really good roasting them all the way
without blanching really did give you a
beautiful intense creamy rich artichoke
flavor it just took way way way way way
too long as far as the appearance as far
as it looking like it's not edible at
all that's actually misleading all the
parts that are too crispy and too dried
out to eat aren't parts you need anyway
those are the outside leaves and the
tops of the leaves all the tender parts
the bottom two-thirds of the leaves the
heart all completely edible and tender
really nice actually and there you go
roasted stuffed artichoke only took two
and a half hours totally not worth it
but that's okay you can still use this
recipe to make some delicious stuffed
artichokes you're just gonna have to
blanch the artichoke first and we'll go
over that on the blog post so head over
to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
[Music]
